note.p: Death: Somerset House, Strand, London, England, Europe (26 January 1674)
Burial: Somerset House chapel, London, England, Europe

Career: Colonel in the Royalist Army (1642-1648); went into exile in France (1649-1660); Envoy to the French Court (1660, 1661); published the play 'The Adventures of Five Hours' in English (1661; 1671)
Committee appointments include: Committee for Foreign Correspondence (1661)
Committee to consider propagating cider-fruit all over England (1663)
Other RSActivity: While abroad, acted as a correspondent in Paris, in particular with the Academy of Sciences at Paris.
Conducted experiments and observations on the ordering and generation of Colchester oysters (1662).
References: E Faure-Fremiet, 'Les Origines de l'Academie des Sciences de Paris' in NR 1966 vol 21 pp 20-31

Notes: The election date is Tuke's re-election date into the Society after the grant of the second charter in April 1663. All Fellows admitted in a two-month window after this charter, until 22 June 1663, are considered Original Fellows. He was previously elected on 6 March 1661.
